Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Analysis for Cognitive Diagnosis - Theory and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Diagnostic classification models are an important statistical tool in cognitive diagnosis and can be employed in a number of disciplines, including educational assessment and clinical psychology. This project focuses on the statistical analysis of cognitive assessment. The research addresses issues concerning fundamental statistical inference and experimental design. It aims at both theoretical development and applications. First, the project will focus on the statistical inference of the item-attribute relationship, which in the current context is formulated as the so-called Q-matrix. The topics include point estimation of the Q-matrix, hypothesis testing, dimension reduction, and model diagnosis. Second, the project will focus on the individualized adaptive design of items so as to measure the attribute profiles more accurately with fewer items. In particular, a criterion is first proposed to measure the efficiency of an item-selection rule based on the large deviations theory. In addition, adaptive item selection schemes are proposed to approach the optimal design.

This research is motivated by applications in educational assessments, psychiatric evaluations, and other disciplines using classification models. In educational applications, the research will help to obtain a data-driven calibration of the skill requirements for exam problems and also to validate the subjective beliefs of such skill requirements, so that better and more accurate assessments of students' knowledge status and skill mastery are obtained. In psychiatric assessment, this study will help to improve evidence-based diagnosis by more accurately identifying the symptom-disorder relationship. The adaptive item selection helps by shortening the lengths of exams (in educational testing) and interviews (in psychiatric evaluation) while maintaining the assessment and diagnosis accuracy. Project results have the potential to positively impact these and other areas of study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research focuses on fundamental statistical inference and experimental design for cognitive diagnosis. It aims at both theoretical development and applications. The proposed research is mainly motivated by applications in educational assessments, psychiatric evaluations, and other disciplines where human characteristics are assessed. In educational applications, this research helps to obtain a data-driven estimate of the skill requirements for each exam problem and also to validate the subjective belief of such skill requirements based on the data. The computerized adaptive tests are applied to high-stakes educational testing programs (such as GMAT, NCLEX, and ASVAB). In mental health surveys, sequential item selection helps to reduce the interview duration and further to improve the response quality.

The scientific work funded by this project has allowed to construct item-attribute relationship (more specifically, the Q-matrix) based on data and to design computerized adaptive testing methods for cognitive diagnosis. The specific results are:

1. Developed identifiability theory of Q-matrix for diagnostic classification models. We provide a theoretical foundation for Q-matrix estimation, more specifically, technical conditions under which the Q-matrix can be estimated consistently based on the data.

2. Developed computationally viable methods for Q-matrix estimation for parametric diagnostic classification models. In particular, we cast the estimation to a latent variable selection problem and employ regularized maximum likelihood. We also developed an online item calibration method for both the Q-matrix entries and item parameters for new items.

3. Developed a Q-matrix estimation method for nonparametric diagnostic classification models via general latent class models and group LASSO.

4. Developed a diagnosis and hypothesis testing procedure for Q-matrix.

5. Developed latent and graphical models for item response data. More specifically, we construct a low-dimensional latent factor model and obtain a good fit to high-dimensional response data by including a graphical structure to the existing models.

6. Developed efficiency measure for item selection for the identification of latent attributes through large deviations theory. In particular, we compute the analytic forms of the asymptotic decay rate of misclassification probabilities that serves as an efficiency measure of item selections.

7. Developed computerized adaptive testing methods for diagnostic classification models. In particular, we developed nearly optimal computerized adaptive testing methods for mastery tests.

8. Developed theoretical results for generalized sequential probability ratio test and asymptotic efficiency results for the generalized likelihood ratio tests.

The research funds were able to partially support the research of one postdoctoral researcher and several PhD students who have finished (or are close to finishing) their dissertations. Several of them have graduated and become faculty members in statistics, psychology, and educational psychology departments across the country.
